metadata.titleEn: HiWATER: Dataset of flux observation matrix (automatic meteorological station of No.16) of the MUlti-Scale Observation EXperiment on Evapotranspiration over heterogeneous land surfaces 2012 (MUSOEXE-12)
metadata.description:
This dataset contains the automatic weather station (AWS) measurements from site No.16 in the flux observation matrix from 1 Jun to 17 September, 2012. The site (100.36411° E, 38.84931° N) was located in a cropland (maize surface) in Daman irrigation district, which is near Zhangye, Gansu Province. The elevation is 1564.31 m. The installation heights and orientations of different sensors and measured quantities were as follows: air temperature and humidity (HMP155; 5 m, towards north), rain gauge (TE525M; 10 m), wind speed (03001; 10 m, towards north), a radiometer (Q7; 6 m, towards south), two infrared temperature sensors (SI-111; 6 m, vertically downward), soil temperature profile (AV-10T; 0, -0.02, and -0.04 m), soil moisture profile (CS616; 0.02, 0.04 m), and soil heat flux (HFT3; 3 duplicates with one below the vegetation and the other between plants, 0.06 m). 
The observations included the following: air temperature and humidity (Ta_5 m and RH_5 m) (℃ and %, respectively), precipitation (rain, mm), wind speed (Ws_10 m, m/s), four-component radiation (DR, incoming shortwave radiation; UR, outgoing shortwave radiation; DLR_Cor, incoming longwave radiation; ULR_Cor, outgoing longwave radiation; Rn, net radiation; W/m^2), infrared temperature (IRT_1 and IR_2, ℃), soil heat flux (Gs_1, below the vegetation; Gs_2 and Gs_3, W/m^2), soil temperature profile (Ts_0 cm, Ts_2 cm, and Ts_4 cm, ℃), and soil moisture profile (Ms_2 cm and Ms_4 cm, %).
The data processing and quality control steps were as follows. (1) The AWS data were averaged over intervals of 10 min; therefore, there were 144 records per day. The missing data were filled with -6999. (2) Data in duplicate records were rejected. (3) Unphysical data were rejected. (4) In this dataset, the time of 0:10 corresponds to the average data for the period between 0:00 and 0:10; the data were stored in *.xlsx format. (5) Finally, the naming convention was AWS+ site no. Moreover, suspicious data were marked in red.
For more information, please refer to Liu et al. (2016) (for multi-scale observation experiment or sites information), Xu et al. (2013) (for data processing) in the Citation section.

background: The two-source energy balance (TSEB) model was successfully applied to estimate evaporation (E), transpiration (T), and evapotranspiration (ET) for land covered with vegetation, which has significantly important applications for the terrestrial water cycle and water resource management. One-source evapotranspiration estimation models combine the soil–vegetation components into a single source. However, in real landscape conditions, the surface is heterogeneous and contains a mixture of soil and vegetation having different temperatures and resistance to energy exchange. Therefore, one-source models explicitly cannot estimate the surface evapotranspiration accurately because the effect of.

Shuttleworth and Wallace proposed a typical two-source evapotranspiration estimation model in which the energy partition is assumed to occur in both “the above canopy” and “the under soil” cases. Water vapor and heat meet over the reference height in the interior of the canopy. Moreover, the mixed water vapor and heat can only exit through the top of the canopy; the total heat flux is in addition to the fluxes coming from every surface layer. However, the model is complex, having over five resistances that cannot be accurately calculated. In addition, the model includes required parameters and observations that cannot be readily obtained from operational satellite- and ground-based data; therefore, the range of applications of the model is limited.

The TSEB model has undergone several revisions, improving the estimation of soil and canopy net radiation, the aerodynamic resistance of the soil surface, the fractional vegetation coverage observed at the radiometer view angle, the distribution of regional-scale near-surface air temperature, and soil and canopy component temperatures. Because the TSEB model only requires the surface energy balance model with a single measurement of land surface temperature, the original model and subsequent refinements have been widely used to estimate E and T under a wide variety of vegetation types, vegetation coverage, climates, and spatial scales. However, most studies have only evaluated the total fluxes or ET (soil plus canopy) in comparison with measurements using the Bowen ratio–energy balance system, the eddy covariance (EC) system, or the large aperture scintillometer.

Accurately estimating surface fluxes in a strongly advective irrigated agricultural area is a particularly challenging task and is even more difficult when the EC flux measurements of H and LE have an incomplete energy balance closure with respect to the available energy Rn−G0. The previous sensitivity studies found that the TSEB model performance is mainly affected by the uncertainty in surface–air temperature difference. Sometimes, this difference is dominant due to the errors in determining the surface soil and vegetation component temperatures from the surface composite radiometric temperature. In this letter, it is shown that there is an overestimation of the component temperatures compared with the observed composite radiometric. This often leads to the most crucial effect on the TSEB model performance. In addition, another factor is the strong advective environment in this region.
research objective: In this letter, the ground-measured soil and canopy component temperatures were used to estimate E, T, and ET, which were better validated with observed ratios of E (E/ET%) and T (T/ET%) using the stable oxygen and hydrogen isotopes, and the ET measurements using an eddy covariance (EC) system.

The objective of this letter is to estimate E, T, and ET using the soil and canopy component temperatures observed via a high-resolution thermal camera as inputs to a series TSEB model and to subsequently better validate E, T, and ET using a combination of the stable oxygen and hydrogen isotope technique and EC measurements.
challenges: However, the current composite temperature separation approaches are limited in their effectiveness in arid regions. Moreover, E and T are difficult to measure on the ground.

Errors in the derived component temperature were primarily caused by image classification errors; these classification errors varied with vegetation abundance. The higher uncertainty of H estimation is not only caused by the uncertainty of the TSEB model but also due to the increased uncertainty of the EC system, which is 18% when the mean H is small in the irrigated farmland. Due to image pixel classification errors, soil pixels were counted as vegetation pixels, which produced an overestimation of the canopy temperature under the developing vegetation abundance. Alternatively, ignoring atmospheric upwelling radiation and transmittance could have produced the uncertainties in the estimated temperatures. In addition, the estimated uncertainty of the incoming short- and long-wave radiation transmittances through the canopy may be another source of Rn estimation errors.
methods: In this letter, the field observations were obtained from the Daman superstation installed in the central oasis, which is a 40-m boundary layer tower located at 100.3722° E, 38.8555° N and at an elevation of 1556 m. The meteorological parameters were measured every 10 min and included air temperature, wind speed, humidity at 5 m over the ground, four-component radiations (measured at 12 m above the ground using a four-component radiometer), and turbulent fluxes (measured at 4.5 m above the ground using an EC system with a sampling frequency of 10 Hz). The soil heat fluxes were measured using three heat plates located 6 cm under the ground. A Fluke Ti55 thermal infrared camera was manually operated on a 25-m-high platform on a boundary layer tower to measure the thermal radiation of the cropland approximately every 120 min; the observations were collected as thermal images from approximately 07:00 to 19:00 China Standard Time (CST) during the daytime. The ground-based measurement data were applied to partition ET into E and T applying the Craig–Gordon model.

To evaluate the TSEB model accurately, the soil heat flux was using the ground measurement. In addition, the soil and canopy sensible heat fluxes were estimated using the series TSEB model, and their latent heat fluxes were calculated while solving the energy balance equations (1) and (2), respectively. The soil and canopy component temperatures were calculated using the images obtained with the thermal camera. To calculate the component temperatures, the visible and NIR images were classified into soil and canopy pixels using the maximum-likelihood method. Next, the soil and canopy directional brightness temperatures were exacted from the thermal images. Finally, the thermal infrared temperatures were converted to the radiation temperatures using the incoming long-wave radiation from the sky and the soil and canopy emissivities. Next, the simulated radiometric temperatures were validated against the surface radiometric temperatures, which were calculated according to the incoming long-wave radiation observed by the four-component radiometer.
dataset: The experimental area is an artificial oasis that is covered with maize, vegetables, and orchards. Data of day of year (DOY) 170, 173, 176, 192, 195, 231, 252, and 256 were used to determine ET and the ratios of E (E/ET%) and T (T/ET%) to ET during the Multi-Scale Observation Experiment on Evapotranspiration over heterogeneous land surfaces, which was part of the Heihe Water Allied Telemetry Experimental Research (HiWATER-MUSOEXE).
findings: Our results indicated that even under the strongly advective conditions, the TSEB model produced reliable estimates of the E/ET% and T/ET% ratios and of ET. The mean bias and root-mean-square error (RMSE) of E/ET% were 1% and 2%, respectively, and the mean bias and RMSE of T/ET% were −1% and 2%, respectively. In addition, the model exhibited relatively reliable estimates in the latent heat flux, with mean bias and RMSE values of 31 and 61 W·m−2, respectively, compared with the measurements from the EC system. These results demonstrated that a robust soil and vegetation component temperature calculation was crucial for estimating E, T, and ET. Moreover, the separate validation of E/ET% and T/ET% provides a good prospect for TSEB model improvements.

Our results demonstrated that the TSEB model using soil and canopy component radiometric temperatures, which were obtained from a high-precision thermal infrared camera, can be applied in a strongly advection-irrigated agricultural area. Notably, the results illustrated that the latent fluxes of the soil and vegetation components were successfully separated with reasonable accuracy, as assessed using ground-based measurements. The estimated E/ET% and E/ET% values agreed well with the values observed using the stable oxygen and hydrogen isotopes technique during the early, middle, and late growing seasons. In addition, the TSEB model produced reliable estimations of Rn, H, and LE; the mean biases of Rn, H, and LE were −18, 5, and 31 W ·m−2, respectively, and the RMSEs of Rn, H, and LE were 29, 19, and 61 W · m−2, respectively. This finding suggests that given accurate soil and vegetation component temperatures, E and T can be accurately separated from ET using the TSEB model.

background: Upscaling of eco-hydrological processes on a heterogeneous surface is a grand challenge. Progress in this field is hindered by the poor availability of multiscale observations. HiWATER is an experiment designed to address this challenge through instrumentation on hierarchically nested scales to obtain multiscale and multidisciplinary data.
challenges: Progress in this field is hindered by the poor availability of multiscale observations.
methods: Several intensive observation periods (IOPs) and continuous hydrometeorological observations were carried out during HiWATER. Only data collected during the IOP in 2012 are presented in this paper. Instruments for the oasis-desert system were arranged in hierarchically nested scales to capture multi-scale eco-hydrological processes. We established a sparse network to investigate the oasis-desert interaction. One superstation was constructed within the oasis, and four EC towers and four two-layer automatic meteorological stations (AMSs) were installed in different landscapes surrounding the oasis, including sandy desert, desert pavement, desert steppe, and wetland. Intensive observations were implemented at the irrigation district scale. A total of 12 airborne remote sensing missions were conducted to cover the FEA using LiDAR, an imaging spectrometer, a multi-angle thermal imager, and an L-band microwave radiometer.
dataset: We introduce a multiscale dataset obtained from Heihe Watershed Allied Telemetry Experimental Research (HiWATER) in an oasis-desert area in 2012. The HiWATER observation system consists of a flux observation matrix of eddy covariance towers, large aperture scintillometers, and automatic meteorological stations; an eco-hydrological sensor network of soil moisture and leaf area index; hyper-resolution airborne remote sensing using LiDAR, imaging spectrometer, multi-angle thermal imager, and L-band microwave radiometer; and synchronical ground measurements of vegetation dynamics and photosynthesis processes. All observational data were carefully quality controlled throughout sensor calibration, data collection, data processing, and datasets generation. The data are freely available at figshare and the Cold and Arid Regions Science Data Centre.

Concept Completion.Answer: intensive observation periods (IOPs), continuous hydrometeorological observations, superstation, EC towers, two-layer automatic meteorological stations, airborne remote sensing missions

Concept Completion.Question: Where are the automatic meteorological stations typically installed within the context of eco-hydrological research?
Concept Completion.Answer: sandy deserts, desert pavements, desert steppes, wetlands

Example.Question: What is an example of a challenge faced in estimating evapotranspiration (ET) using remote sensing data in arid regions?
Example.Answer: A challenge is the limited effectiveness of current composite temperature separation approaches in arid regions, where errors in image classification can lead to overestimation of canopy temperature due to soil pixels being counted as vegetation pixels.

Example.Question: Could you provide an example of a multiscale observation dataset available for eco-hydrological research in oasis-desert areas?
Example.Answer: An example is the dataset obtained from the Heihe Watershed Allied Telemetry Experimental Research (HiWATER) in 2012, which includes data from a flux observation matrix, eco-hydrological sensor network, and hyper-resolution airborne remote sensing, available at figshare and the Cold and Arid Regions Science Data Centre.

Feature Specification.Question: What are the main characteristics of the data collection methods used in eco-hydrological experiments over heterogeneous land surfaces?
Feature Specification.Answer: ground-based measurements, remote sensing techniques, meteorological parameters, soil heat fluxes, flux observations, eddy covariance system, LiDAR, imaging spectrometers, multi-angle thermal imagers, L-band microwave radiometers, hierarchically nested scale, multi-scale eco-hydrological processes, irrigation district scales

Feature Specification.Question: What specific features of the soil and canopy are critical for accurately estimating evapotranspiration in agricultural areas?
Feature Specification.Answer: soil and canopy component temperatures, soil and canopy sensible heat fluxes, latent heat fluxes, soil and canopy directional brightness temperatures, radiation temperatures, accurate classification of soil and canopy pixels

Quantification.Question: How many layers of soil moisture sensors are used in the data collection method in this field?
How many intensive observation periods were conducted during the HiWATER experiment in 2012?
Quantification.Answer: The exact number is not specified.

Definition.Question: What defines 'eddy covariance (EC) system' as a data collection method for measuring surface fluxes?
Definition.Answer: The eddy covariance (EC) system is a technique for measuring the turbulent fluxes of heat, water vapor, and momentum between the land surface and the atmosphere. It involves high-frequency measurements of meteorological parameters, such as wind speed and air temperature, and is used to validate estimates of evapotranspiration and other surface fluxes.

Comparison.Question: How do the data collection techniques used in the HiWATER experiment, which includes airborne remote sensing and ground-based measurements, compare to the methods used for collecting data in the Heihe Watershed flux observation matrix?
Comparison.Answer: The HiWATER experiment employs a hierarchical approach with multiscale instrumentation, including LiDAR, imaging spectrometers, and multi-angle thermal imagers, to capture eco-hydrological processes across various scales. In contrast, the Heihe Watershed flux observation matrix focuses on a combination of eddy covariance towers, large aperture scintillometers, and automatic meteorological stations for localized measurements, highlighting a more ground-centric data collection strategy.

Comparison.Question: What are the challenges in estimating evapotranspiration using the TSEB model compared to the challenges faced in upscaling eco-hydrological processes in the HiWATER experiment?
Comparison.Answer: The TSEB model faces challenges primarily related to the uncertainty in surface-air temperature differences and errors in component temperature estimation. These difficulties are exacerbated by the strong advective conditions and inaccuracies in image classification. On the other hand, the HiWATER experiment's challenges stem from the poor availability of multiscale observations necessary for upscaling eco-hydrological processes, which the experiment seeks to address through its comprehensive, multiscale data collection methodology.

Comparison.Question: How do the methods for ensuring data quality and control in the flux observation matrix compare to those employed in the HiWATER experiment's multiscale dataset?
Comparison.Answer: The flux observation matrix ensures data quality by addressing issues such as missing data, duplication, and out-of-range values, utilizing a systematic approach to maintain consistency. Similarly, the HiWATER experiment emphasizes rigorous quality control through sensor calibration, precise data processing, and dataset generation, ensuring high reliability and accuracy across its multiscale observations.

Interpretation.Question: How can the implementation of hierarchically nested scales improve the accuracy and reliability of data collected in heterogeneous environments?
Interpretation.Answer: In a dataset, hierarchically nested scales were used to collect multiscale and multidisciplinary data, capturing eco-hydrological processes in oasis-desert systems. This approach allows for a comprehensive understanding of interactions across different landscapes, improving data accuracy and reliability.

Interpretation.Question: What are the potential challenges in using thermal infrared cameras for measuring soil and canopy component temperatures, and how might these affect data interpretation?
Interpretation.Answer: The use of thermal infrared cameras involves challenges such as image classification errors, which can lead to overestimation of canopy temperatures. These errors impact the accuracy of component temperature calculations and thus affect the interpretation of latent heat fluxes and evapotranspiration measurements.

Interpretation.Question: In what ways can the use of stable isotopes improve the validation of evapotranspiration estimates in arid regions?
Interpretation.Answer: Stable isotopes, such as oxygen and hydrogen isotopes, provide an additional method for validating evapotranspiration estimates by offering observed ratios of evaporation and transpiration. This approach can enhance the accuracy of model validations, particularly in arid regions where traditional methods face limitations.

Causal Antecedent.Question: What factors contribute to the complexity of accurately estimating evapotranspiration in heterogeneous landscapes using remote sensing and ground-based data?
Causal Antecedent.Answer: The complexity arises from the heterogeneous nature of the landscape, which contains a mixture of soil and vegetation with different temperatures and resistances to energy exchange. Additionally, the complexity of models like the two-source energy balance (TSEB) model, which requires multiple parameters and observations not readily available from operational satellite and ground data, further complicates accurate estimation.

Causal Antecedent.Question: Why is it particularly challenging to achieve energy balance closure in strongly advective irrigated agricultural areas when using eddy covariance systems?
Causal Antecedent.Answer: Achieving energy balance closure is challenging due to the incomplete energy balance closure with respect to available energy (Rn−G0) in such environments. The TSEB model performance is mainly affected by uncertainty in surface-air temperature differences, which are dominant due to errors in determining surface soil and vegetation temperatures, further complicated by the strong advective conditions of the region.

Causal Antecedent.Question: What causes the limitations in current composite temperature separation approaches for estimating soil and canopy temperatures in arid regions?
Causal Antecedent.Answer: The limitations are primarily due to image classification errors, which vary with vegetation abundance, causing soil pixels to be misclassified as vegetation pixels. This leads to an overestimation of canopy temperature, especially under developing vegetation abundance. Additional uncertainties arise from ignoring atmospheric upwelling radiation and transmittance and errors in estimating incoming short- and long-wave radiation transmittances through the canopy.

Causal Consequence.Question: How might the use of a high-resolution thermal camera impact the accuracy of soil and canopy component temperature measurements in estimating evapotranspiration?
Causal Consequence.Answer: The use of a high-resolution thermal camera can significantly improve the accuracy of soil and canopy component temperature measurements, which in turn enhances the estimation of evapotranspiration. Accurate temperature data allows for more precise separation of latent fluxes and provides reliable estimates of evaporation and transpiration ratios, even in strongly advective conditions.

Causal Consequence.Question: What is the effect of poor availability of multiscale observations on the progress of upscaling eco-hydrological processes?
Causal Consequence.Answer: The poor availability of multiscale observations hinders progress in upscaling eco-hydrological processes, making it challenging to capture and analyze the interactions across different scales. This limitation affects the ability to develop comprehensive models and understand complex interactions, thereby reducing the effectiveness of eco-hydrological research.

Goal Orientation.Question: What is the primary goal of employing a flux observation matrix and automatic meteorological stations in the context of eco-hydrological research over heterogeneous land surfaces?
Goal Orientation.Answer: The primary goal is to address the challenge of upscaling eco-hydrological processes on a heterogeneous surface by obtaining multiscale and multidisciplinary data through instrumentation on hierarchically nested scales, as demonstrated in the HiWATER experiment.

Goal Orientation.Question: What are the objectives behind conducting intensive remote sensing missions using technologies like LiDAR and multi-angle thermal imagers in oasis-desert ecosystems?
Goal Orientation.Answer: The objectives are to capture multi-scale eco-hydrological processes by observing the interactions between oasis and desert systems, and to collect high-resolution data that can be used to understand the dynamics of these heterogeneous landscapes, contributing to the goals of the HiWATER project.

Instrumental/Procedural.Question: What are the specific steps involved in setting up a flux observation matrix for monitoring evapotranspiration in a heterogeneous landscape?
Instrumental/Procedural.Answer: The setup involves using a flux observation matrix that includes eddy covariance towers, large aperture scintillometers, and automatic meteorological stations. These instruments are arranged hierarchically in nested scales to capture multi-scale eco-hydrological processes, such as those in the oasis-desert system. The matrix also integrates soil moisture and leaf area index sensor networks, and incorporates hyper-resolution airborne remote sensing technologies like LiDAR, imaging spectrometers, multi-angle thermal imagers, and L-band microwave radiometers.

Instrumental/Procedural.Question: How is the Two-Source Energy Balance (TSEB) model applied to estimate evaporation and transpiration using observed soil and canopy temperatures?
Instrumental/Procedural.Answer: The TSEB model estimates evaporation (E) and transpiration (T) by using ground-measured soil and canopy component temperatures. These temperatures are obtained from high-resolution thermal cameras and are used as inputs to the TSEB model. The model separates the latent heat fluxes of soil and canopy by solving energy balance equations and validates the component temperatures against surface radiometric temperatures. Additionally, the model uses the Craig–Gordon model to partition ET into E and T.

Enablement.Question: What technological advancements enabled the collection of multi-scale eco-hydrological data in oasis-desert areas?
Enablement.Answer: Technological advancements such as the installation of a flux observation matrix of eddy covariance towers, large aperture scintillometers, automatic meteorological stations, and hyper-resolution airborne remote sensing using LiDAR, imaging spectrometer, multi-angle thermal imager, and L-band microwave radiometer enabled the collection of multi-scale eco-hydrological data in oasis-desert areas.

Expectation.Question: Why might multiscale observations be challenging to collect in heterogeneous landscapes such as oasis-desert systems?

Expectation.Question: What factors could lead to inaccuracies in estimating soil and canopy temperatures using remote sensing techniques?
Expectation.Answer: Errors in derived component temperatures were primarily caused by image classification errors, which varied with vegetation abundance. Especially in arid regions, soil pixels might be misclassified as vegetation pixels, leading to overestimations of canopy temperature under developing vegetation abundance.

Expectation.Question: What expectations should researchers have regarding the quality control measures necessary for collecting datasets in eco-hydrological experiments?
Expectation.Answer: All observational data in eco-hydrological experiments like HiWATER are expected to undergo rigorous quality control measures, including sensor calibration, data collection, processing, and dataset generation, ensuring reliable and accurate data.

Judgmental.Question: How would you assess the challenges faced by researchers in obtaining accurate component temperatures for the two-source energy balance model in strongly advective environments?
Judgmental.Answer: Researchers face significant challenges in obtaining accurate component temperatures for the two-source energy balance model in strongly advective environments due to errors in image classification and uncertainty in estimating radiometric temperatures. The complexity of separating composite temperatures into soil and canopy components, particularly in arid regions, further complicates the task. These challenges are compounded by the need to accurately classify pixels in thermal images and account for atmospheric effects on radiation measurements.

Judgmental.Question: In your opinion, what are the key considerations for ensuring the quality and reliability of datasets collected from eco-hydrological experiments over oasis-desert areas?
Judgmental.Answer: Key considerations for ensuring the quality and reliability of datasets collected from eco-hydrological experiments over oasis-desert areas include meticulous quality control measures during sensor calibration, data collection, data processing, and dataset generation. Assertion.Answer: Challenges in measuring soil and canopy temperatures separately using remote sensing technologies in strongly advective environments include errors caused by image classification, pixel misclassification, and uncertainties in temperature estimation due to atmospheric conditions. Request/Directive.Question: Please provide a detailed analysis of multiscale data collection methods used for measuring evapotranspiration over heterogeneous land surfaces in eco-hydrological experiments.
Request/Directive.Answer: Multiscale data collection methods in eco-hydrological experiments, such as those in the HiWATER project, involve hierarchically nested instrumentation to capture multiscale and multidisciplinary data. This includes the use of flux observation matrices with eddy covariance towers, large aperture scintillometers, and automatic meteorological stations. Additionally, hyper-resolution airborne remote sensing using LiDAR, imaging spectrometer, multi-angle thermal imager, and L-band microwave radiometer are employed, along with synchronical ground measurements of vegetation dynamics and photosynthesis processes.

Request/Directive.Question: Please outline the challenges associated with collecting accurate evapotranspiration data in strongly advective irrigated agricultural areas.
Request/Directive.Answer: Challenges in collecting evapotranspiration data in strongly advective irrigated agricultural areas include the incomplete energy balance closure of EC flux measurements with respect to available energy, and uncertainty in surface-air temperature differences. Errors in determining surface soil and vegetation component temperatures from composite radiometric temperature can lead to overestimation, affecting model performance. There is also increased uncertainty due to image classification errors and the strong advective environment in these regions.

Request/Directive.Question: Please explore potential strategies for improving dataset accuracy and quality control in large-scale eco-hydrological experiments.
Request/Directive.Answer: Improving dataset accuracy and quality control in large-scale eco-hydrological experiments can involve several strategies, such as ensuring sensor calibration and consistent data collection protocols. Quality control processes include removing duplicate records, eliminating data that exceed physical or instrumental limits, and standardizing date and time formats. Additionally, utilizing high-precision thermal infrared cameras for accurate soil and vegetation component temperature measurements and implementing robust classification algorithms for image processing can further refine data quality and model accuracy.
